replication_study.hypothesis: Higher individual concern about immigration is associated with higher distrust in the national parliament, controlling for standard predictors of political trust (e.g., interpersonal trust, economic satisfaction, ideology, demographics).

data_plan.source_type: Survey-derived analytical dataset (likely derived from ESS-style variables based on naming and paper context)
data_plan.wave_or_subset: To be determined from dataset metadata; expected to correspond to multiple country-rounds similar to ESS Rounds 1–4
data_plan.sample_size: To be determined upon loading (will report N rows)
data_plan.access_details: Files are provided locally under /app/data; no external access required.

qualification.explanation: The provided RDS datasets (data_clean.rds, data_imp_5pct.rds, data_clean_5pct.rds) appear to be cleaned analytical samples intended for modeling trust and immigration concern, aligning with the focal hypothesis. If these are derived from ESS-like data, they constitute an independent re-sample or alternate processing suitable for testing robustness of the phenomenon.
qualification.similarity_to_original: Original paper uses ESS Rounds 1–4 with individual-level measures of political distrust and immigration concern (post_registration.json: original_study.data.source and method). The replication data include cleaned, model-ready RDS files and an R analysis script (replication_data/data_analysis_code.R) suggesting similar constructs and analysis intent.
qualification.deviation_from_original: Exact waves/countries are not yet confirmed for the replication dataset. We will extract metadata (e.g., country, round, year) from the RDS columns to document deviations. If the replication data include a different subset (e.g., different years, countries, or imputation scheme such as 5% variant files), that constitutes a new sample while maintaining construct comparability. Sources for original scope: post_registration.json; sources for replication scope: replication_data folder contents.

data_plan.notes: We will verify that the dataset includes: (1) a distrust in parliament variable (0–10/11 scale), (2) an immigration concern index, and (3) control variables mirroring the original. If variable names differ, we will map them explicitly in the Python code. All I/O will use /app/data and outputs will be saved alongside inputs. Any imputation in data_imp_5pct.rds will be documented.

planned_method.steps: 1) Load the RDS dataset (prefer data_clean.rds; if multiple-imputation or 5% variants are intended by the R code, follow that selection). 2) Inspect columns and confirm presence of outcome (distrust in parliament), main predictor (immigration concern), and key controls. 3) Recode or normalize variables if specified in the original modeling (e.g., reverse codes, scale ranges). 4) Fit a regression model predicting distrust in parliament from immigration concern and controls. 5) Conduct robustness checks (alternative controls, heteroskedasticity-robust SEs). 6) Save model summary and key coefficients to /app/data and produce comparison-ready metrics.
planned_method.models: Linear regression with robust standard errors; optionally mixed-effects (random intercepts by country/country-round) if grouping variables are present.
planned_method.outcome_variable: Distrust in the national parliament (continuous scale, expected 0–10/11).
planned_method.independent_variables: Concern about immigration (composite or index variable).
planned_method.control_variables: Interpersonal trust; economic satisfaction/dissatisfaction; income difficulty; life satisfaction/unhappiness; health and education satisfaction; ideology (left-right); household income; age; education; gender; governing party support; and available contextual variables if present.
planned_method.tools_software: Python (pandas, numpy, pyreadr or pyarrow/feather if needed, statsmodels, linearmodels or mixed-effects via statsmodels MixedLM).

planned_estimation_and_test.estimation: Coefficient on immigration concern in the regression of distrust in parliament.
planned_estimation_and_test.test: t-test on the immigration concern coefficient (two-sided), with robust SEs; if mixed-effects, Wald z/t with cluster-robust SEs if feasible.

planned_method.missing_data_handling: Primary: listwise deletion for the main model using data_clean.rds; secondary: use data_imp_5pct.rds if multiple imputation is embedded, and compare results.
planned_method.multiple_testing_policy: If multiple outcomes (e.g., distrust in politicians, legal system) are analyzed, apply Holm-Bonferroni correction; focal primary outcome is parliament distrust without correction.
planned_method.inference_criteria: Significance at alpha=0.05 (two-sided); expected positive direction for immigration concern; report coefficient, SE, p-value, and 95% CI.

files.replicate_analysis__py.py: Python script that: (1) loads /app/data/original/13/0112_python_gpt5/replication_data/data_clean.rds (or data_imp_5pct.rds as needed), (2) identifies/renames variables to match outcome and predictor, (3) fits the specified regression (and mixed-effects if grouping variables exist), (4) outputs a JSON/CSV summary of the immigration concern coefficient, SE, p-value, N, and model specification to /app/data.
files.variable_mapping__py.py: Helper utility to map dataset-specific column names to standardized names (e.g., distrust_parliament, concern_immigration, controls). Reads the dataset columns and returns a mapping dictionary used by replicate_analysis__py.py.
files.README_replication_code.txt: Brief instructions to run the replication: python replicate_analysis__py.py; describes expected inputs under /app/data and produced outputs.

codebase.notes: The original code is in R (replication_data/data_analysis_code.R). Per policy, we will translate to Python rather than execute R. All file paths will use /app/data. Dependencies include pyreadr to load RDS. If pyreadr cannot load the RDS format, we will fallback to pyarrow/feather if applicable or request a CSV export.

analysis.instructions: 1) Ensure the dataset files exist at /app/data/original/13/0112_python_gpt5/replication_data/. 2) Run: python replicate_analysis__py.py. 3) The script will load data_clean.rds by default, infer/match variable names, and fit the regression. 4) Outputs: /app/data/replication_results.json (key coefficients) and /app/data/model_summary.txt.
analysis.comparison_metrics: Compare sign and significance of the immigration concern coefficient; compare magnitude (per-one-unit effect) with the original reported effect (post_registration.json numerical results for parliament ~0.17). Report standard errors, p-values, and model fit (R^2 for OLS; ICC if mixed-effects).
